content:
Updated the first part of the statement from "A terrible tragedy has stuck on Bobsville, ..." to the correct version - "A terrible tragedy has struck Bobsville, ...".

edit: Was leaving it for the creator but people approved it, so I changed myself.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: it's a solid but challenging question

there is something off in this puzzle...

why in 'Centre Test' case
Input
5 5
2 3
12111
23331
23331
11111
12231
Output
1 1

you can put a house of height 2 and length 3 on a land 333
but in Validator 1 
Input
4 5
2 2
11332
21321

Output

you can not put a house of height 2 and length 2 on a land 33 witch start in '0 2'

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Puzzle trÃ¨s bien dÃ©crit, qui peut Ãªtre rÃ©solu rapidement.
Il combine les compÃ©tences acquises en rÃ©alisant les puzzles 'Island Escape' et 'Longest coast' tout en Ã©tant original donc en gardant tout son intÃ©rÃªt.

A nice puzzle, that could be an extension of the 'Island Escape'.

Good idea!
Beautiful clash

Fun clash.

I wonder if the term "first" is even needed at all? While it is easy to infer based on experience, just using top-most and left-most provides the same information without any ambiguity. (see replies for example)

edit: 
"A terrible tragedy has stuck on Bobsville, ..." should be changed to "A terrible tragedy has struck Bobsville, ..."

It was cool, but I found it kinda difficult.
I usually finish most Clash of Code in less than 10 minutes (often around 5 minutes), but this one took me between 15 and 30 minutes.
I know my coding skills arenâ€™t that high, but this definitely felt harder than the other clashes Iâ€™ve done so far.
To me, it was almost more of a puzzle than a coding challenge.

One last thing: I think there were way too many tests. Since the goal is to find the answer quickly, waiting for all the tests to run took quite a while.

But I had fun anyway â€” thanks for the contribution!

Nice clash. :)

Solved in 5 minutes, but I was confused about what "first" means in this context...

Your solution prioritises having a small row co-ordinate over a small col co-ordinate, but that's not clear in the statement.

I tested both methods and they both get 100% so it doesn't matter with your tests, but the lack of clarity was a bit confusing. If you had a test case where "0 5" was a valid answer but so was "1 0" then it's arguable that "1 0" is closer to the top-left and therefore should win, but your code would preference "0 5" because it checks rows first.

Maybe you could reword it as:
"The first valid area being the <<top-most>> (1st priority) and <<left-most>> (2nd priority) coordinates."

Also, Validator 1 is the only test case where the answer is the very last corner - a literal 'corner case' ðŸ˜…
It's probably good to move this a bit later and have a matching test case for it. It's easy to get confused with the ranges you're checking here and forget to check the final bounds:
I found these tests and validators fail when you mess up h and/or w ranges by 1:
both: V1,V2,T3,T5,V5
h: V1,V2,T3,V5
w: V1

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice brute force puzzle that is quite straightforward to implement.

Seems like a straightforward puzzle :) Some minor thoughts I had:

- The "height" of the land and the "height" of the home seemed to be referring to the same thing at first. Also somewhat related: "width" could be ambiguous when relating to the grid.
- For clarity, consider stating that the house should not be rotated (i.e., a 3x1 house should not be built on a 1x3 plot of land).
- Consider specifying constraints so that players will know to consider the brute-force solution :)
- For clarity, you can define what "first" valid area means: scanning the grid by row from top to bottom, scanning left to right for each row, and selecting the first found area. Although, I think this should be rather intuitive once players see the test cases.

Stub generator
* Lines 1 & 2: Please use different variable names. The stub generator doesn't distinguish between uppercase and lowercase (you may click TEST IN IDE to see the default code for yourself).

Input
* Lines 1 & 2 & their descriptions: Please use the updated variable names.

* Please change the second "Line 1" to "Line 2".

Output / Cases / Solution
* Output section states "Not Found" but the expected output in cases and your solution code shows "NO PLACE" instead. Please be consistent.

Cases
* Please swap/revise cases so that each validator is similar to its corresponding test. For example (but not limited to this example), cases requiring output of "NO PLACE" should be paired up.

Thanks.
Hadn't realized that was the case for the stub generator, should be fixed now. The other careless mistakes should also be fixed now

Thank you for your suggestion, I had thought the whole â€œheightâ€ thing couldâ€™ve been confusing as well. These suggestions have been taken into consideration and the challenge has been altered accordingly
7 visible tests is't that many really. There can be as many as 25 visible tests (with 25 corresponding validators). ðŸ˜‰
What changes would you suggest?

Might be missing your meaning but the bottom right corner when starting at '0 2' is '1 3' and is a 2, not a 3 - Therefore they're at different elevations so can't be built there... Let me know if I understood right

ooh... you right.... i misunderstood the puzzle... i thought the plot of land represented by a 2D grid was in a upper view... where the height of the house had to be fitted in only on one row of the grid... 

i might suggest to change height of the house to width of the house... i think that's why i don't get the puzzle until now

Something simple along the lines of:

Your task is to output the top-left coordinate (0-based) of the top-most and left-most valid area. If there's no valid area, output Not Found.

Says the same thing but shorter.
There is 14 validators when I test this clash in the IDE, witch took between 1 and 2 minutes to pass.

14 validators is because it's now in contribution review mode. In the actual clash, you'll see the 7 cases labelled "TEST" only, and your submitted code is assessed using the other "invisible" cases labelled "VALIDATOR".
Ah, okay, I didnâ€™t know that â€” this is the first contribution Iâ€™m testing. Thanks for the info!
No worries! ðŸ˜‰

Goal
* Please fix the typo: "lenght" => "length".

Thanks.
